projects.title: Data Library
projects.description: an end‑to‑end UX for the Data Library—a core experience that helps admins organize, clean, and manage data for retrieval augmented generation (RAG).

details.tagline: Helping admins organize and manage data for AI-powered experiences.
details.challenge: As more customers started experimenting with GenAI, one big theme kept surfacing: managing data was confusing and time‑consuming. Admins needed a simple and dependable way to organize content, configure response behaviors, and ensure the output from agents was grounded in the right data.
details.problem:
When an agent is trained on irrelevant or outdated content, it produces unreliable answers. Too much data leads to slow responses. Poorly processed data results in hallucinations. A structured pipeline—similar to washing, sorting, and storing clothes—becomes essential to keep things efficient.

In RAG, the steps mirror this process:
details.goals:
1. Organize and control their data sources
2. Ensure responses were accurate and grounded
3. Understand what was happening behind the scenes
details.successMetrics:
Working with PMs and engineering, we established two foundational strategies:
a. One library with multiple data sources → one retriever → lower compute costs
b. Query once instead of multiple times

projects.title: Agent Builder Platform
projects.description: no-code platform that enables businesses to create and deploy AI agents without any technical expertise.

details.tagline: Build your AI agent and deploy in minutes
details.overview: My role focused on shaping the end-to-end agent creation experience for the MVP, from defining the scope and user journeys to designing interaction patterns that could scale as new agent types were introduced to the Agentforce platform.
details.challenge: AI agents unlock significant value for enterprises and creating them typically requires deep technical knowledge, long setup times, and close collaboration with engineering teams. This creates friction for business users who want to experiment, iterate, and deploy agents quickly.
details.problem:
I partnered with our Research & Insights team at Salesforce to interview our top 20 customers at Salesforce to understand their pain points while building an AI agent. 

Our research revealed 3 core challenges: 
1. High cognitive load: Users struggled to understand what an 'agent' was and how to configure one. 
2. Unclear starting points: Too many tools and open-ended prompts. 
3. Low confidence in outcomes: Users were unsure whether their agent would behave as expected once deployed.
details.goals:
1. Create an AI agent without writing code
2. Understand what the agent will do before deployment
3. Feel confident iterating or updating the agent later
details.successMetrics:
Reduce time to first value:
1. Time to first agent created: ≤ 10 minutes
2. Time to first successful deployment: ≤ 20 minutes

Successful agent creation:
1. Agent creation times: 70-85% for first-time users
2. Setup Abandonment rate: <30%

Validate MVP use cases match real demand.
1. Sales Agent: 40–50%
2. Customer Support Agent: 30–40%
3. Sales Coach: 15–25%
details.solution: We landed on a hybrid approach: a guided flow with smart defaults that adapts based on the user's experience level. The key insight was providing progressive disclosure—showing complexity only when needed.

customSections.title: Structuring the creation flow
customSections.content: Step-by-step creation flow that introduces the agent purpose upfront, progressively disclosed complexity and uses plain language instead of AI jargon.

customSections.title: Reducing the cognitive load
customSections.content: Limited configuration in the early steps. Used templates and pre-filled defaults per use case. Clearly separated 'required' vs 'advanced' settings.
